DOC.HEAD: Government Leaders, Newspapers Unite To Condemn Bloody Repression ^With PM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Government leaders and newspapers throughout Europe, displaying rare unison across East-West borders, today denounced the Romanian government for its bloody repression of weekend protests. Scores, perhaps hundreds, of people were reported killed when Romanian security forces crushed anti-government demonstrations on Saturday and Sunday, according to unconfirmed reports. Gunfire was said to have also been heard today in Timisoara, 30 miles from the Yugoslav border. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, at a session with some 200 members of the European Parliament in Brussels, said that if reports of bloodshed are true, ``I can only express my very profound regret. ``We are categorically opposed to the use of force,'' Shevardnadze said. There was no comment in Beijing, where the Chinese government crushed a peaceful pro-democracy movement with tanks on June 4-5. In its first protest to another Soviet bloc country, the Bulgarian government today expressed ``serious concern'' to the Romanian Embassy in Sofia over the unilateral closure of the border. Romania closed its borders to all visitors, allowing in only diplomats and others with official papers. Foreign ministers of the 12 European Community nations denounced the violence to suppress the demonstrations. Several governments summoned Romanian diplomats to protest. In Brussels, the 12 foreign ministers said in a statement the regime of President Nicolae Ceausescu was ``turning its back on all the commitments concerning human rights to which it has subscribed.'' In Poland, both Parliament and Nobel Prize winner Lech Walesa unanimously denounced the human rights abuses and demanded Romania stop the violence. The British government summoned Romanian Ambassador Stan Soare to protest ``in the strongest possible terms'' about the violent crackdown. A spokesman said Soare responded to the British protest by ``resorting to the tired old formula of alleging interference in Romania's internal affairs.'' ``We urgently called upon the Romanian government to end policies of repression and allow their citizens to exercise their fundamental human rights,'' the Foreign Office said. In neighboring Hungary, feelings ran high because as many as 1.7 million ethnic Hungarians live in Transylvania in the western part of Romania. ``Anachronistic regimes opposed to progress cannot remain in place'' if Europe is to be united, liberal Hungarian Premier Miklos Nemeth said. ``History has already witnessed the reign of regimes, not so long ago, that showed off their strength with tanks before being overthrown by the rage of the people,'' the Hungarian Socialist Party newspaper Nepszabadsag said.
